SENT.plain: Magnetic resonance (MR) examinations of three patients with rhinocerebral mucormycosis are reviewed
The clinical course is outlined and the MR characteristics are analyzed in light of the known pathology
The major MR findings include sinus and orbital disease followed by deep facial extension
Involvement of basal portions of the hemispheres, brain stem, and hypothalamus occurred rapidly following ipsilateral facial or orbital invasion in all three cases
Regions of intracerebral inflammation were hyperintense compared with normal parenchyma on T2-weighted and proton density-weighted images
Septic cavernous sinus and internal carotid artery thrombosis was diagnosed by MR in one case
Magnetic resonance demonstrated partial resolution of intracerebral abnormalities that accompanied clinical improvement in the one surviving patient
